data.title: Finland's new government takes office
data.text:
Petteri Orpo, leader of the National Coalition Party, speaks to the press before the government negotiations at the House of the Estates in Helsinki, Finland, on May 2, 2023. (Photo by Matti Matikainen/Xinhua)

The government consists of the prime minister and 18 ministers from the National Coalition Party, the Finns Party, the Swedish People's Party, and the Christian Democrats.

HELSINKI, June 20 (Xinhua) -- The new government of Finland, led by Prime Minister Petteri Orpo, took office on Tuesday.

The government consists of the prime minister and 18 ministers from the National Coalition Party, the Finns Party, the Swedish People's Party, and the Christian Democrats.

Orpo said in his speech during the government's welcome visit to the presidential palace that the Finnish people have "voted for change." The government parties are united in their view of the state of public finances, he said, adding: "We must tighten our belts."

Born in November 1969, Orpo was first elected as a member of Parliament in 2007. Before serving as prime minister, he held three different positions as a member of two governments, including minister of Agriculture and Forestry, minister of the Interior, and minister of Finance. He was elected leader of the National Coalition Party at the party conference in the summer of 2016.

(L-R) Chairs of the Finnish Christian Democrats, the Finns Party, the National Coalition Party, and the Swedish People's Party, which constitute the new coalition government of Finland, pose for a photo during a press conference in Helsinki, Finland, June 16, 2023. (Photo by Matti Matikainen/Xinhua)

In its first plenary session on Tuesday, the new government decided on the division of responsibilities among ministers, the composition of ministerial committees and working groups, and deputizing arrangements for ministers. The Orpo government also outlined the government program to Parliament. â–
